title: Who was ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi and what atrocities did he inspire
text:

ISIS terror mastermind Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi's reign of terror is believed to have come to a bloody end after he was killed in a top secret raid overnight.

The Islamic State leader, described as "one of the most evil men in history", has spent years in hiding after the US placed a $25million bounty on his head in 2016.

But in the last few hours - and under the cover of darkness - the fugitive is understood to have been killed in a series of explosions in Syria.

It is believed the mission was ordered by US President Donald Trump , who posted a cryptic tweet saying: "Something very big has just happened!".

Hate-filled Baghdadi, 47, was one of the most-wanted men after inspiring atrocities and spreading poisonous messages encouraging violence, such as the Manchester Arena bombing.

And the secretive character's death will be seen as a huge victory for many.

Who is he?

(Image: Getty)

Al-Baghdadi was the Iraqi jihadist who rose from obscurity to declare himself "caliph" of all Muslims as the leader of Islamic State.

He was born Ibrahim Awad al-Samarrai in 1971 in Tobchi, a poor area near the town of Samarra, north of the Iraqi capital Baghdad, whose name he took.

His family includes preachers from the ultra-conservative Salafi school of Sunni Islam, which sees many other branches of the faith as heretical and other religions as anathema.

He became active in al-Qaeda following the US-led invasion of Iraq in 2003 and spent time in the infamous Abu Ghraib detention centre.

The Iraqi-born cleric, 47, who had a number of wives, went on to become leader of ISIS in 2010 and led the terror group to huge territorial gains across Iraq and Syria.

(Image: US DEPARTMENT OF STATE)

It was not until July 4, 2014, that he seized the world's attention, climbing the pulpit of Mosul's medieval al-Nuri mosque in black clerical garb during Friday prayers to announce the restoration of the caliphate.

"God ordered us to fight his enemies," he said in a video of the occasion, which presented him as "Caliph Ibrahim,commander of the faithful".

Thousands of volunteers flocked into Iraq and Syria from around the world to become "Jund al-Khilafa" - soldiers of the caliphate and join him in his fight against the Shi'ite-led Iraqi government and its U.S. and Western allies.

His acts of atrocity

Under his leadership, ISIS fought back government forces in Syria and Iraq, claiming huge areas of oil-rich land populated by millions of people.

Its terrorists murdered thousands of people in acts of horrific brutality - including capturing Westerners who were beheaded on camera.

The genocide of Yazidis, adherents of one of the Middle East's oldest religions, illustrated the brutality of his rule.

Thousands of men were slaughtered on their ancestral Sinjar mountain in northwestern Iraq and women were killed or taken as sex slaves. Some other religious groups suffered sexual slavery, slaughter and floggings.

The group also caused global revulsion with beheadings of hostages from countries including the United States, Britain and Japan.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

He taunted Western forces with his “bin Laden-style” messages to followers, in one video he is filmed with an AK47 assault rifle by his side.

A former Western intelligence officer previously said: “Al-Baghdadi is a very important figurehead for Islamic State and getting him is a very high priority.

"His leadership of Daesh has been punctuated with some of the vilest act of violence against human beings by terrorists."

The group claimed responsibility for or inspired attacks in dozens of cities including Paris, Nice, Orlando, Manchester, London and Berlin, and in nearby Turkey, Iran, Saudi Arabia and Egypt.

In Iraq, it staged dozens of attacks on predominantly Shi'ite Muslim areas.

A truck bomb in July 2016 killed more than 324 people in a crowded area of Baghdad, the deadliest attack since the 2003 U.S.-led invasion of Iraq.

The group also carried out many bombings in northeast Syria, which has been under the control of U.S.-backed Kurdish forces.

Colonel Richard Kemp, former adviser to the Government on terrorism, said earlier this year: “Baghdadi is one of the most evil men in history and inspires his followers in the Middle East and around the world to acts of the most medieval barbarity.

“We need to get him urgently to stop his poisonous message encouraging global violence, including savage attacks in Britain like we saw at the Manchester Arena in 2017.”

The hunt for Baghdadi

The search for the 47- year-old Islamic State leader was described as a "kill or capture" mission.

SAS troopers previously joined up with American Special Forces in the search, which also involved MI6, UK listening station GCHQ and the American National Security Agency.

They focused the manhunt on the most hostile of Iraq’s towns and villages.

Around 30 SAS and Special Boat Service troops were previously involved in the hunt, led from a special forces HQ north of Baghdad.

Iraq’s “Golden Division” special forces were also involved, helping to secure areas when search missions are called in.

RAF drones launched from a base in Kuwait, and flown by “Reaper squadron” pilots based at RAF Waddington, in Lincolnshire, were being deployed on 12-hour surveillance missions.

(Image: AL-FURQAN MEDIA/AFP via Getty Im)

The drones were armed with four Hellfire missiles which can be fired remotely once a target is identified.

Drones patrolling Al Anbar and Mosul Provinces were searching for cars being driven by al-Baghdadi’s brother or driver.

A senior source previously said: “Nobody wants to allow Baghdadi to spit out hate-filled messages and a lot of people are on the mission to stop him.

“It is not known where al-Baghdadi is, but every suspicious movement on the ground is being monitored and, even though he is the most careful of the high-value targets, he will make a mistake.

“They always make a mistake in the end – and then he will be either trapped or killed.”

His last message

Most of Baghdadi's speeches were distributed as audio recordings, a medium better suited to the secretive, careful character.

It was this elusiveness that for a long time helped him evade the surveillance and air strikes that killed more than 40 of his top commanders.

On September 16, Islamic State's media network issued a 30-minute audio message purporting to come from Baghdadi.

In the clip, he said operations were taking place daily and called on supporters to free women jailed in camps in Iraq and Syria over their alleged links to his group.

"As for the worst and most important matter, the prisons, the prisons, oh soldiers of the caliphate. Your brothers and sisters; do your utmost to free them and tear down the walls restricting them," he said.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

In the audio message, Baghdadi also said the United States and its proxies had been defeated in Iraq and Afghanistan, and that the United States had been "dragged" into Mali and Niger.

At the height of its power Islamic State ruled over millions of people in territory running from northern Syria through towns and villages along the Tigris and Euphrates valleys to the outskirts of the Iraqi capital Baghdad.

But the fall in 2017 of Mosul and Raqqa, its strongholds in Iraq and Syria respectively, stripped Baghdadi, an Iraqi, of the trappings of a caliph and turned him into a fugitive thought to be moving along the desert border between Iraq and Syria.

U.S. air strikes killed most of his top lieutenants, and before Islamic State published a video message of Baghdadi in April there had been conflicting reports over whether he was alive.

Despite losing its last significant territory, Islamic State is believed to have sleeper cells around the world, and some fighters operate from the shadows in Syria's desert and Iraq's cities.

How is he believed to have died?

Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi is believed to have been killed in a U.S. military operation in Syria.

A U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that Baghdadi was targeted in the overnight raid but was unable to say whether the operation was successful.

The operation involved helicopters, warplanes and a ground clash in the village of Brisha near the Turkish border.

Dramatic footage has emerged appearing to show the raid in which several explosions can be seen and heard.

A huge fireball erupts in the sky followed by a cloud of smoke and several deafening bangs.

There is then deadly silence.

Day-time video shows a crater in the ground littered with torn, blood-stained clothes.

Newsweek claimed that Baghdadi detonated a suicide vest after realising he had no chance of escape.

His two wives were also reportedly killed in the firefight, with no injuries to US forces.

Two Iraqi security sources and two Iranian officials said they had received confirmation from inside Syria that Baghdadi had been killed.

One of the Iraqi officials said: "Our sources from inside Syria have confirmed to the Iraqi intelligence team tasked with pursuing Baghdadi that he has been killed alongside his personal bodyguard in Idlib after his hiding place was discovered when he tried to get his family out of Idlib towards the Turkish border."

The Britain-based war monitor the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said nine people were killed during the two-hour raid, including two women and likely at least one child.

One house thought to be the main target was badly hit from the air, before fighters descended from helicopters and engaged in ground clashes.

President Donald Trump's cryptic message

Trump gave an indication that something was afoot on Saturday night when he tweeted without explanation, "Something very big has just happened!"

White House spokesman Hogan Gidley announced late on Saturday that Trump would make a "major statement" at 9 a.m. EST (1pm UK time ) on Sunday.

Gidley gave no further details.

Trump has faced withering criticism from both Republicans and Democrats alike for his U.S. troop withdrawal from northeastern Syria, which permitted Turkey to attack America's Kurdish allies.

Many critics of Trump's Syria pullout have expressed worries it would lead the Islamic State militancy to regain strength and pose a threat to U.S. interests.

An announcement about Baghdadi's death could help blunt those concerns.
description: ISIS terror mastermind Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, described as "one of the most evil men in history", inspired brutality, fear and spread poisonous messages
